data.text: 1.1. The Trust has a responsibility to provide an efficient, high quality service that achieves the best possible health outcomes for patients, at a sustainable cost.

1.2. There are a number of different circumstances that may necessitate the redeployment of staff. It is the policy of the Trust to seek to retain employees wherever possible and all reasonable efforts will be made to find alternative employment for those affected employees.

1.3. This procedure outlines circumstances necessitating the redeployment of employees which include the Trust Disciplinary Policy and Performance Improvement Policy and Organisational Change Policy re-organisation.

1.4. Organisational Change: It is the requirement of the Trust to continually change the composition of their workforce in order to meet the operational needs of the service by ensuring they employ the right level of employees in terms of numbers, skills and cost. The roles that employees undertake may need to adapt to take the following into account:-
Changes in service delivery;
New and improved ways of working;
Changes to workload or skills requirements;
Introduction of new technology;
Legislative or economic changes;
Changes to commissioning contracts – investments and disinvestments.
1.5. Health related Capability

1.5.1 Should an employee be unable to continue or return to their job role due to their health, managers must ensure that redeployment is considered. This is to ensure that an employee's experience and skills are not lost to the Trust and to comply with the requirements of the Equality Act 2010. Occupational Health and Human Resources must be involved and Occupational Health will have to advise on the suitability of potential alternative roles. Please also refer to the Trust Sickness Management policy in these circumstances.

1.5.2 Should an employee require redeployment due to being unable to continue to carry out their normal job duties as a result of disability, this procedure is to be followed for managing their redeployment. The employee should be treated sensitively and in accordance with the Equality Act 2010 under which it is unlawful to unjustifiably discriminate against an employee on the grounds of disability. Human Resources and Occupational Health must be involved and their advice and input sought by line managers.
1.6. Where an employee has not been able to meet or sustain a satisfactory standard of their job duties/requirements but may instead be able to carry out the duties and
responsibilities of another role, redeployment options should be explored in line with the Trust Performance Improvement policy.
1.6.1. Where an employee is required or requests to change their post following a Grievance/disciplinary case which has been upheld:-

1.6.2 It may be in the best interests of those involved that redeployment of one or other of the employees be considered. Advice should be sought from HR. Please also refer to the Trust Bullying and Harassment, Grievance and Disciplinary policies.

1.6.3 Redeployment will not apply if an employee requests to change their post following a bullying/harassment, grievance or disciplinary case which was not upheld. Please also refer to the Trust Bullying and Harassment policy, Grievance or Disciplinary policy as appropriate. The employee may, of course, choose to apply for other roles within the Trust of their own volition.
1.6.4 If an employee is at risk due to being unable to find a job share partner please also refer to the Trust Flexible Working Policy.
2.1. This procedure should be used in conjunction with the Organisational Change Policy.

2.2. This procedure applies to all employees of Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust (MEHT), Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust (SUHFT) and Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust (BTUH)). It does not apply to Contractors, Bank staff, Agency or Volunteer workers.

2.3. In order to meet changing needs more effectively, there may be occasions when managers need to implement relatively minor changes. Minor changes and adjustments to duties and working practices may be implemented without recourse to formal procedures set out in this document but any reasonable minor change can only be implemented following consultation with employee/employees affected. When such changes are proposed discussions between HR and the Staffside Site Lead will take place.

3.1. The purpose of this document is to set out the procedure to be followed in circumstances where employees are required to be redeployed and to ensure that this is carried out in a fair and equitable manner.

3.2. The procedure outlines the support available to employees whose role and continued employment is at risk and the steps managers should take to reduce the possibility that an employee may have to leave the Trust.
3.3. The procedure supports the Trusts aim to retain employees with a range of relevant skills and experience wherever possible across the Trust.

data.text: 5.1. Managers

5.1.1. Managers  in  conjunction  with  the  Trust  Human  Resources  department  are responsible for implementation of this procedure into practice within their service areas. As such, managers should liaise with the Trust Human Resources Department throughout.
5.1.2. Managers are critical to the redeployment process and should must ensure that they are receptive to the concerns of their team members.

5.1.3. Managers must ensure that individuals are not discriminated against directly or indirectly on the grounds of protected characteristics, i.e. ethnic origin, nationality, race, disability, gender, marital or partnership status, age, religion or belief, sexual orientation or transgender status, when applying this policy.
5.1.4. Managers should ensure that they engage with and keep Union representatives informed throughout the process.

5.1.5. In organisational change situations, it is acknowledged that managers managing the redeployment of employees may also be affected by change. However, there is a need for transparency, even if they themselves are affected, and managers should communicate and respond to employees appropriately in line with their role and responsibilities to ensure that they are fully aware and supported through the changes taking place.
5.1.6. Managers should discuss the situation with their team members and document conversations and meetings in writing, to ensure there is a written account.

5.1.7. Managers will contact their finance representative at the earliest opportunity so that any financial consequences of redeployments can be accounted for appropriately. This includes the employee remaining on their original budget whilst undertaking trial periods.

5.1.8. Managers should ensure that they are familiar with the Trust services to support redeployment such as the Employee Assistance Programme, Occupational Health, People and Organisation Development Department and Human Resources.
5.2. Employees
5.2.1. Employees are expected to familiarise themselves with this procedure and the Trust approach to managing redeployment.
5.2.2. Employees should play an active role in the redeployment process in identifying possible new career and employment opportunities for themselves.
5.2.3. Employees are expected to provide information for use in the redeployment process, e.g., the completion of the Application Form for Redeployment (Appendix 1) in a timely and complete manner.
5.2.4. Employees are required to actively search for alternative roles and undertake trial periods in posts that are identified, as well as undergo relevant training required.
5.3. Trade Unions

5.3.1.  Trade Unions play a vital role in advising and representing employees undergoing redeployment and in working with managers to ensure that redeployment is managed with the least disruption to services and patients and in accordance with the principles of avoiding compulsory redundancies or the termination of contracts of employment wherever possible.
5.4. Human Resources

5.4.1. Human Resources are responsible for ensuring that the procedure is applied fairly and consistently. Should Human Resources have concerns about its application, these should be escalated to the HR Lead/Group HR Director as appropriate.
5.4.2. Human Resources are responsible for ensuring managers understand their role and responsibilities under this procedure.
5.4.3. Human Resources must ensure that the documentation relating to redeployment is appropriate and compliant with Trust policies and that the procedure is followed accurately.
5.4.4. A member of the Human Resources department will support the manager at meetings where required.

5.4.5. The Human Resources department will keep up to date the redeployment register ensuring that it is updated with accurate details of employees requiring redeployment; opportunities being explored; trial periods being undertaken and the outcome.
5.5. Communications

5.5.1  Provide guidance and advice to managers to ensure communication is consistent, ensuring it is in line with Trust corporate style, branding and wider communication strategy, both internally and externally during reorganisations and the redeployment of employees.

5.5.1.  Manage the external public relations in relation to the redeployment of employees, including releasing information to the press, public bodies where required and in responding to press enquiries.
6.1.  The following key principles will apply:
6.1.1. Employees will be treated as individuals with due regard to their personal and employment circumstances and their career aspirations at all stages of the redeployment procedure.

6.1.2. The principles of partnership working will be applied to redeployment situations. Individual employees or employee groups affected by the need for redeployment and their accredited recognised trade union representative(s) will be appropriately consulted with.

6.1.3. The Trust is committed to minimising uncertainty and insecurity for employees affected by the need for redeployment. As such, security of employment will be maintained wherever possible and redeployment is the Trust preferred option.
6.1.4. Employees who are displaced will be supported through reasonable retraining to assist them in securing alternative employment.

6.1.5. In organisational change situations, compulsory redundancies will be avoided wherever possible, however where it is not possible for compulsory redundancies to be avoided, the Trust will ensure that the total number of proposed redundancies will be kept to a minimum.
6.1.6. The Trust is not required or expected to create new roles but to consider for redeployment existing roles that become vacant.

7.1. The Trust will seek to avoid, dismissals, by offering redeployment opportunities within the Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust where the employee has the skills and experience to undertake the identified role.

7.2. Alternative employment is work within the Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust that is on broadly similar terms and within the same range of skills required as the substantive employment. It may be on any site operated by the Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust subject to consideration of the individual's personal circumstances such as travel, caring responsibilities or mutually agreed flexible working arrangements that are in place or that could facilitate alternative employment.
7.3. There may also be opportunities for offering redeployment opportunities within other NHS Trusts, where the employee has the skills and experience to undertake the identified role.

7.4. Reasonable re-training opportunities (taking into account cost and time period) will be offered where the employee has the potential to undertake an alternative role after a defined period of development.
7.5. Where an employee has a disability in line with The Equality Act 2010, reasonable adjustments will be considered to support redeployment.

8.1. The redeployment period will last for a duration of 12 weeks, however where the employee is at a crucial point, for example, awaiting interview outcome or awaiting outcome of trial period, it may be reasonable to extend the employees redeployment period by a maximum of  weeks. Advice should be sought from the Human Resources representative before action taken.

An employee who is being managed in line with the Trust Sickness Management policy and procedure and for whom redeployment is being explored should not be prevented from progressing through the stages of the Sickness Absence procedure. It should be noted that the redeployment period of  week commences from the point at which it is agreed that redeployment options within the Trust will be explored.

An employee who is being managed in line with the Trust Performance Improvement policy should have discussions during the process regarding the option of redeployment to another role within the Trust that may be a better fit with their skills and experience. The redeployment period of  weeks should commence at the point of agreement on redeployment option.

9.1. Once an individual has been established as having redeployment status, a meeting should be held as soon as possible with the employee, their line manager and a Human Resources representative. The employee may bring a trade union representative or work colleague to this meeting if they wish. The purpose of the meeting is to:-
(a) Explain the redeployment procedure and the employee's status within it.

(b) Inform the employee of the Trust website address on which they can view vacancies, TRAC and in addition to the national website (www.jobs.nhs.uk). The employee must be made aware that they must meet the essential criteria as stipulated in the job description (person specification).

(c) Provide the employee with a copy of the Application Form for Redeployment (See Appendix 1). Request that the employee complete and return the Application Form for Redeployment to the Human Resources representative at the earliest opportunity following the meeting.
(d) Identify the employees preferences in respect of redeployment where possible i.e. site, hours, type of role etc. although there can be no guarantee employees may be offered their preference.

(e) Help identify the employee's skills, current and previous work experience so they can incorporate these details into the Application Form for Redeployment (See Appendix 1), which will be used to ‘match' the employee to vacant posts. The employee should also detail on the Application Form for Redeployment how their skills and experience match the essential criteria on the relevant job specification. In the instance of health redeployment this would also be done in line with Occupational Health recommendations as far as reasonably practicable. Employees should be assessed by Occupational Health prior to being matched to a post.

(f) Counsel the employee and give advice, bearing in mind the availability of employment opportunities across the Trust. Look at the availability of training courses within the Trust that might be appropriate to assist the employee to gain redeployment.
(g) Agree the date that the redeployment period will commence, and end and a review date if necessary.

(h) For redeployment on grounds of reorganisation/restructuring the search for redeployment will commence on the date the employee is notified that they have been formally declared at risk of redundancy (normally after not being successful in securing a post as a result of organisational change) and continue

throughout the employee's redundancy notice period. For employees' whose contractual notice period is less than the  week redeployment period, the notice period will be extended to enable the redeployment period to be completed. In these circumstances, the employee will be advised that the Trust will wish to understand any decision not to apply for or accept an offer of alternative employment. Unreasonable refusal to apply for a post, or refusal of a job offer, may affect the employee's right to receive redundancy pay.

(i) Discuss with the employee whether assistance with interview skills and/or a CV workshop would be beneficial. The Human Resources representative will be responsible for making any necessary arrangements.

9.2. The content and outcome of the meeting should be confirmed in writing along with the date that the redeployment period is to commence and end within 7 calendar days. A copy of the relevant Trust policy and procedures should also be enclosed with the letter.

9.3. During the redeployment period the line manager should hold regular meetings with the employee to review progress and offer support. It may be necessary for the Human Resources representative to attend these meetings and the employee will have the right to be accompanied by trade union representative or work colleague. During these meetings, the Human Resources representative and line manager will keep details of redeployment logged in Appendix 2, which will be kept on the employees' personal file. Appendix  will outline vacancies that have been put forward to the employee as potential alternatives, vacancies the employee has applied for, log trials and the outcomes to each. The manager and Human Resources should also ensure that consideration be given to potential vacancies that may be in the pipeline.

9.4. The affected employee will be expected to be proactive in the search for alternative employment and should notify their Human Resources representative if any of the vacancies viewed are of interest.
9.5. To express an interest in a vacancy that is already advertised, employees must contact the Human Resources representative as soon as possible and before the closing date.
9.6. Employees will be entitled to priority of consideration for vacancies deemed by the line manager and Human Resources representative to be a potential match.

10.1. Once an employee is given notice of redundancy, or is being managed under the formal stages of the Trust Sickness Management, Performance Improvement policies or requires redeployment due to disability, the responsible Human Resources representative will add the employees' name to the redeployment register held within the Human Resources department.

10.2. The purpose of the redeployment register is to ensure that employees are considered for vacancies where possible before they are advertised, in order for the Trust to support them in finding alternative employment within the Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust.

10.3. Employees on the redeployment register are required to provide all relevant information and the correct documentation to the line manager and Human Resources representative in a timely manner, to ensure that they can be considered for redeployment opportunities without undue delay.

10.4. Employees will remain on the redeployment register until the end of their redundancy notice period or for those whose contractual notice period is for less than the redeployment period of 12 weeks, they will have their notice period extended to enable the redeployment period to be completed.

10.5. Regular contact will be maintained with the individual employee to ensure that all options for redeployment are brought to their attention. Opportunities may be within the same department, within the same hospital site or the Mis and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust.

10.6. Employees on maternity leave will be placed on the redeployment register as and when appropriate in consultation with them. Contact will be maintained between the employee and Human Resources on an agreed basis subject to individual circumstances.

10.7. Employees on long term sickness absence, will be placed on the redeployment register in consultation with them when and as appropriate. Contact will be maintained between the employee and Human Resources on an agreed basis subject to individual circumstances.

10.8. Employees with frequent/intermittent sickness absence that are confirmed by Occupational Health to have an underlying health condition will be placed on the redeployment register in consultation with them when it is expected that another role within the Trust may be better suited to them taking into consideration their health condition.

11.1. The preliminary match is the initial point which identifies those vacancies in which aspects of the job description, person specification and advert are considered to be a match for the employee.

11.2. If a preliminary match to a post is considered as an alternative, or the employee has identified a post for which they wish to apply, the Human Resources representative will explain to the Recruiting Manager that the employee is seeking redeployment along with limited information about the reason for redeployment following a prior conversation and with agreement from the employee

11.3. Should the vacancy have been advertised, the Human Resources representative will contact the Recruitment Advisor to request that any non-redeployee applications for the post(s) are placed on hold. A post can be put on hold if a redeployee becomes available at any time before an offer of employment is made through the normal recruitment process. The Human Resources representative will contact the Recruiting Manager of the request and provide necessary information.
Selection

12.1.1 Where the Recruiting Manager considers that the employee meets the essential criteria for a vacant post (as defined within the person specification), they will be required to confirm with the Human Resources representative that the post is a match.

12.1.2 Where a match is confirmed, the Recruiting Manager will arrange for an informal structured interview to be held. The purpose of this is to assess the employee's suitability for the post or is able to meet the essential criteria within a reasonable timespan if provided with relevant reasonable support and/or training.

12.1.3 Where the employee is successful following the informal structured interview, the Recruiting Manager will arrange for the employee to commence a trial period. The Human Resources representative will be duly informed that a trial period is to commence so that this can be appropriately recorded and tracked and the post will therefore not need to be advertised.

12.1.4 Where more than one employee in a redeployment situation has been identified as a potential candidate for the vacant post, such eligible employees will be considered and the appointment will be based on matching the best candidate available to the requirements of the post. This may include the eligible employees undergoing a competitive interview in order to confirm a match. Interview for all potential redeployees will be organised as soon as is reasonably practicable by the Recruiting Manager. At this stage, offers will be made purely on the basis of the employee's performance at interview and will be subject to successful completion of a trial period.

12.1.5 Following a successful match, the Human Resources representative will liaise with the employee, their current line manager and Recruiting Manager to organise the commencement date of the trial period.
Non-Selection

12.2.1 Where an employee in a redeployment situation has been put forward for priority of consideration and is not selected, the Recruiting Manager is required to contact the Human Resources representative to discuss the reasons for the decision. The reasons will need to be recorded, in writing, and appropriate feedback given to the employee by the recruiting manager or the line manager.

12.2.2 Any post identified as a match, which does not result in a redeployment candidate being appointed into the post, will be subject to review by the Human Resources representative prior to the advertisement of the post.

12.2.3 Where an employee in a redeployment situation is put forward for consideration but refuses to be considered for the post or rejects an offer of a redeployment post, they must inform the Human Resources representative of their reasons, in writing, within 7 calendar days of being put forward or being offered the role. If the new job is deemed a match, as determined by the Trust, and the employee refuses to accept the redeployment, the employee forfeits any right to a redundancy payment.

12.2.4 If the candidate for redeployment does not meet the specified criteria and the vacant post is not considered a match, the employee may still apply for the post through the normal recruitment process.

13.1. In accordance with statutory requirements, in Organisational Change circumstances, where redeployed employees are offered a new position, a trial period of 4 weeks but may be extended up to  weeks by mutual agreement where an employee requires additional training and development. There is no statutory entitlement to a trial period for redeployments due to other circumstances, e.g. health. However, the Trust recognise that the purpose of the trial period is for both the Trust and the employee to establish whether the job is in fact suitable for the employee. Therefore, a trial period is recommended best practice in all redeployment circumstances.

13.2. The trial period will commence on the day they start work under the new contractual arrangements. The trial period will normally last for 4 weeks by mutual agreement where an employee requires additional training and development. The Human Resources representative should be informed if a decision is taken that the trial period should be extended.

13.3. During a trial period, the Recruiting Manager will meet with the employee on a regular basis to set SMART objectives, review progress and identify any areas where further training or support may be required. This will be achieved through a programme agreed by the responsible manager and the employee, in consultation with the Human Resources representative.
13.4. Once the trial period has commenced, the trial period and the process can be paused, if needed. If the role is deemed unsuitable during this trial period, the
employee will re-enter the redeployment process at the point that the initial trial period ceased.
13.5. At the end of the trial period, the manager and the employee will advise the Human Resources representative, in writing, whether or not the appointment is considered a match.
13.6. If agreement cannot be reached between the manager and the employee on the suitability of the appointment, further advice should be sought from Human Resources.

13.7. If there is any sickness (which is unrelated to the reason for redeployment) or annual leave during the trial period, the length of the trial period may be adjusted to ensure the redeployee has the four weeks trial period. Trial periods can only be extended in exceptional circumstances.

13.8. If sickness occurs during the trial period and this is related to the reason for the redeployment, an assessment will need to be made regarding whether the post is a match. The redeployee, will in this situation, be re-referred to Occupational Health. If Occupational Health considers that the post is no longer suitable, the trial period will be deemed to have ended.
13.9. The search for other potential alternative employment will be suspended until the outcome of the trial is known.
13.10. Throughout the trial period, the employee's substantive employing department will continue to pay the employee.

13.11. When an employee successfully completes their trial period, the Recruiting Manager should inform the Human Resources representative and complete and forward Evaluation Form of the trial period (See Appendix 1, part 4) to the Human Resources representative. The line manager will organise for a staff change form to be completed and sent to the Human Resources Department. The Human Resources Department will issue an amendment to contract to the employee and a copy will be kept on the employee's Human Resources personnel file. Employment checks and ESR will be updated, as appropriate.

13.12. Where the appointment is not confirmed following a trial period, written reasons must be provided by the Recruiting Manager to the Human Resources representative and where accepted, alternative options, including reinstatement on the redeployment register, will be discussed with the employee, by the original line manager, according to the circumstances of the situation. Appropriate feedback will be provided to the employee at the end of the trial period.
13.13. If the employee leaves the Trust during or at the end of the trial period, the employee forfeits their right to a redundancy payment (in Organisational Change situations).

13.14. If during the course of the trial period, the role is evidently deemed unsuitable, the trial can be stopped at any stage. Advice must be obtained from the Human Resources Department prior to stopping the trial period.

14.1. Where a Recruiting Manager and the Human Resources representative are of the view that a redeployment opportunity is an alternative role but the employee does not agree, the reasons for this should be confirmed by the employee, in writing, to the Recruiting Manager and the Human Resources representative, within 7 calendar days. If the Recruiting Manager and Human Resources representative remain of the view that it is an alternative role and the employee unreasonably refuses to accept the role, the employee may forfeit any rights to a redundancy payment (in Organisational Change situations).

14.2. If no redeployment opportunities have been identified by one or more parties, i.e. the Recruiting Manager, the employee being considered for redeployment, Human Resources or Occupational Health, there may be no alternative other than to consider the grounds for dismissal. The relevant Trust policy under which the grounds for redeployment were established will be referred to:
If the redeployment was as a result of Organisational Change, the Organisational Change policy should be referred to.
If the redeployment was a result of Performance Improvement policy should be referred to.
If the redeployment was as a result of Health, the Sickness Management policy should be referred to.
15.1. Redeployment due to health:
Pay protection does not apply where an employee chooses to accept a role at a lower banded pay or a role with reduced hours.
15.2. Redeployment due to performance:
Pay protection does not apply where an employee chooses to accept a role at a lower banded pay or a role with reduced hours.
15.3. Redeployment due to organisational change:

An employee who is required by the Trust to be redeployed into a post as a result of service or organisational change may be entitled to protection of pay and conditions of service. Please refer to the Trust Organisational Change policy and Appendices 1, 2, and  of the Organisational Change Policy for further information.

16.1.  All best efforts should be made to resolve any issues informally; however, employees have the right to appeal against the application of this procedure by invoking the Grievance Procedure and setting out the grounds for their appeal, e.g. selection for redeployment.

17.1.  This procedure is in immediate effect from its agreement date. There are no specific training requirements. Advice and support on the implementation of this procedure is available via the Human Resources department.

18.1. All management of redeployment and outcomes of all cases handled under this procedure will be monitored by the Human Resources department in partnership with the  relevant  Staff-Side  Representatives.  The  aim  will  be  to  ensure  that  any redeployment process is managed appropriately as per this procedure.
18.2. This procedure is due to be reviewed in 3 years.

A change to an existing policy
A change to the way staff work
What are you proposing to change?

The introduction of a Redeployment Procedure to be used across the Trust ensuring consistency and effective processes are in place to help with the redeployment of employees by finding alternative employment for those affected.
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)

The need for the redeployment of employees can be due to a number of factors including organisational change, capability arising from health or disability and capability (performance). Having a procedure agreed across the Trust will ensure fair and consistent practice.
Who benefits from this change and how?
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change?
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change? b) If so, with whom?

The procedure has been shared across the HR function for feedback and has also been shared with Staff-Side Chairs, inviting them to comment on the procedure. As this is a procedure and not a policy, full ratification is not required.
